title: What are the pros and cons of FreeBSD and Linux? - Quora

response.answer_text: I'm pretty much on board with Marcas Neal's answer, with a slight caveat. That used to be universally true, not so much anymore. For me, all of the BSD descendants are much more powerful, intuitive and stable than all of the Linux distros. They're as simple as possible, but no simpler. Linux, on the other hand, is vast, prolific and ubiquitous. It's impossible to find developers that haven't at least heard of it, very difficult to find those that haven't used it (even among the hard-core MSFT .NET developer crowd), and not uncommon to find those who have dove into the kernel sources. These days, with Amazon AWS providing a heavily supported Linux version, more and more backend is running on Linux, and less and less on some BSD variant. The primary advantage that Linux has over BSD is ubiquity. It's literally everywhere, and no matter what distro you want to run, there's a really large community of people who can help you figure out how to do whatever it is that you're trying to do.  Plus, it's something your boss has heard of, so when you say "I want to do this in Linux" it's not likely to provoke a "what the hell is that" response. The primary advantage that BSD has over Linux is that BSD, ah, how to put this politely... Oh well, I'll just go for it. BSD *typically* hasn't had the internals meddled with by amateurs. The guys that wrote the core code are alpha technologists who learned their craft from the people who invented the technologies. It's at worst, 2nd generation from core code. Linux?  I don't even recognize the names of some of the people with commits. It's probably 5th generation from origin.  Sometimes, that's a good thing. When I, personally, look at the vast feature creep that's happened in Linux over in particular the last five years, I think it's not, in this case.

FreeBSD and Linux system are two free, open supply systems. Indeed, their users can simply check and modify the ASCII text file with an absolute freedom. Linux is something you will be able to use for game servers or embedded systems or as desktop OS. FreeBSD was perpetually meant to be an extremely stable server OS. Free BSD software is same as Free BSD UNIX but not a by-product of UNIX. This software was developed by the Berkeley package Distribution in 1993. FreeBSD ASCII text source code is usually discharged under a permissive BSD license. As numerous set of server-related code is embedded in FreeBSD, it is possible to use it as a mail server, web server, FTP server and as a router. Linux is UNIX-like, open supply, and community-developed software for computers, servers, mainframes, mobile devices and embedded devices. Linux is packaged in a shape called a Linux distribution (or distro for quick) for each desktop and server use.
